An update for the `arrows` pr:
All the scaling attributes now apply to 3d arrows as well, meaning the arrow tail and tip can be scaled independently again. I disconnected some faces which cleaned up the shading and seems to perform a little better too. I also added an `align` attribute so one can center 3d arrows at the given positions more easily.

messages.text:
The current system just differentiates between `button down` and `button up` so you have to do something like `if ispressed(scene, button) && was_not_pressed` to figure that out. You also can't stop events because Observables just call everything that's connected to them.

Both are things I tried to fix in <https://github.com/JuliaPlots/AbstractPlotting.jl/pull/634>. `events.mousebutton` and `events.keyboardbutton` are little structs there, with press/repeat/release information in  `action` fields. All the events are changed to `PriorityObservables` that are ordered by a `priority::Int8` you can set, and that will stop propagating an event if a listener returns true. Because of that event listeners only work with `on` and should always return a `Bool`.

If you're trying to make a game that pr should be quite helpful, I think. It would also be nice for me if someone tried that pr and told me if anything is broken or weird. I was using it for a couple of weeks without issues, but I also wasn't making a game...

messages.text:
```using Interact, GLMakie
@manipulate for i in slider(1:0.01:2, value = 1, label = "move")
    fig = Figure(resolution = (400, 400))
    ax = Axis(fig)
    lines!(ax, 1:10, (1:10).^i)
    fig[1,1] = ax
    limits!(ax, 1,10,1,100)
    fig
end```

elements.text:
using Interact, GLMakie
@manipulate for i in slider(1:0.01:2, value = 1, label = "move")
    fig = Figure(resolution = (400, 400))
    ax = Axis(fig)
    lines!(ax, 1:10, (1:10).^i)
    fig[1,1] = ax
    limits!(ax, 1,10,1,100)
    fig
end

```    t, x, θ = move!(τ, t, x, θ, f, Flow)```
and
```    if rand() < alpha
        ...```
by
```X = Node([point(x0)])
contour3d!(lscene, r, r, potential, levels=30, linewidth=3.0)
scatter!(lscene, X, marker=MARKER, color=:red, markersize=200)
...
while true
    t, x, θ = move!(τ, t, x, θ, f, Flow)

    if ispressed(canvas.scene, <http://Keyboard.space|Keyboard.space>) 
       ...
end```

messages.text:
On categorical ticks: It seems that categorical ticks broke with the `Figure` update, because the keywords in `PlotSpec(points, tickranges = xyrange, ticklabels = labels)`  don’t get forwarded to the axis. Is that correct?

Assuming that this will take some time to be fixed, I would like to have a robust way to fix the ticks manually.

Right now the positions are determined by mapping `unique(categorical_x)` to `1:length(unique(categorical_x))`. So you can’t really change the order.

What do you think about using DataAPI.jl instead? Something like

```categorical_labels(xs)       = DataAPI.levels(xs)
categorical_range(xs)        = values(DataAPI.refpool(xs))
categorical_position(xs, x)  = DataAPI.invrefpool(xs)[x]```
One could add a third category to the categorical trait
```# Trait for categorical values
struct Categorical end
struct HasRefPool end # the better Categorical
struct Continous end

categorical_trait(::Type, x) = !isnothing(refpool(x)) ? HasRefPool() : Categorical()```
What do you think?

I might work on a PR when I feel like procrastinating the next time.

root.text:
On categorical ticks: It seems that categorical ticks broke with the `Figure` update, because the keywords in `PlotSpec(points, tickranges = xyrange, ticklabels = labels)`  don’t get forwarded to the axis. Is that correct?

Assuming that this will take some time to be fixed, I would like to have a robust way to fix the ticks manually.

Right now the positions are determined by mapping `unique(categorical_x)` to `1:length(unique(categorical_x))`. So you can’t really change the order.

What do you think about using DataAPI.jl instead? Something like

```categorical_labels(xs)       = DataAPI.levels(xs)
categorical_range(xs)        = values(DataAPI.refpool(xs))
categorical_position(xs, x)  = DataAPI.invrefpool(xs)[x]```
One could add a third category to the categorical trait
```# Trait for categorical values
struct Categorical end
struct HasRefPool end # the better Categorical
struct Continous end

categorical_trait(::Type, x) = !isnothing(refpool(x)) ? HasRefPool() : Categorical()```
What do you think?

I might work on a PR when I feel like procrastinating the next time.

messages.text:
Ok people one of the longest-standing PRs is finally merged, and we now have text in screen-space! This means one can use `text!` more intuitively, and specify the text size independent of data scaling, while specifying the position in terms of data. Previously, the text would be squished. Here's one simple example:

```data = cumsum(randn(1000))
lines(data)
text!("maximum", position = reverse(findmax(data)))
text!("minimum", position = reverse(findmin(data)), align = (:left, :top))
current_figure()```

messages.text:
And here's another new feature / improvement. If you specify limits for an axis, they are now by default "sticky" if you add new plots to it. ctrl+click resets to those limits, and ctrl+shift+click calculates new autolimits and makes those sticky. This happens either with the `limit` keyword, or `xlims!`, `ylims!`, `limits!` and `autolimits!` That's what happens in this video:
```julia> f = Figure(resolution = (800, 800)); Axis(f[1, 1], limits = (-5, 5, -5, 5)); f

julia> scatter!(randn(100, 2))```

messages.text:
I've merged the new `Axis3` as an experimental feature into the main branch so you can try it out. It's not used by default in order to not be breaking, but you can either construct it specifically via `Axis3(fig)` etc, or you pass `type = Axis3` to the `axis` keyword when plotting, like this:
```using GLMakie
using FileIO

brain = load(assetpath("brain.stl"))
colors = [tri[1][2] for tri in brain for i in 1:3]

mesh(
    brain,
    color = colors,
    colormap = Reverse(:Spectral),
    figure = (resolution = (1000, 800), fontsize = 14),
    axis = (
        type = Axis3,
        aspect = :data,
    )
)```

One way is to hide decorations and spines, and set the figure padding to 0.
```f, ax, im = image(randn(20, 20))
f.layout.alignmode[] = Outside(0)
hidespines!(ax)
hidedecorations!(ax)
f```

messages.text:
When making an animation in (GL)Makie, what are some recommended ways to clear the scene every frame? Is there a more idiomatic/nicer way to do it other than using `delete!(scene, scene.plots[1])` below?
```scene = Scene(resolution=(1000, 1000), show_axis=false)
record(scene, "test.mp4") do io
    for t in range(0, 1, length=25)
        if !isempty(scene.plots)
            delete!(scene, scene.plots[1])
        end
        surface!(scene, 0:0.1:10, 0:0.1:10, (x,y) -> rand())
        update!(scene)
        recordframe!(io)
    end
end```

messages.text:
<@UK1BNFHFV> I just put up the small package I was mentioning the other day ("AlgebraOfGraphics without the magic") <https://piever.github.io/SplitApplyPlot.jl/dev/>. It is basically a `groupby`, where the "combining function" receives an axis on which to plot as well as the selected columns and the grouping variables (with the scales applied already). This last bit may change, they could receive also the original value, or some smart type that combines both things in a sensible way.

 Definitively still WIP, but I hope this approach works to integrate statistical plots with MakieLayout. I'm using it for a "Makie-based dashboard", but I suspect it may become AlgebraOfGraphics backend (or even replace AoG altogether, if the syntax stays manageable).

messages.text:
Is there a way to get both the "top" side and "bottom" side of a surface to look the same with light bouncing off it correctly? Right now I have a non-orientable surface, so the surface normals can't continuously change over the whole surface so at these discontinuities the light bouncing effect is off. It seems like the surface normals determine how light might bounce off it, so the top side with the "correct" surface normal looks great, but the bottom side looks flat with no shading/light highlights. (EDIT: I am currently using `surface` )
(EDIT: Alternatively, is there a way to manually edit the surface normals of a surface? I could fake the effect to hide the surface-normal discontinuities. I found surface_normals but it doesn't seem to be what I'm looking for)
